Searches for specific records or returns all records.

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: Select or map the base that contains the table you want to search for records.
Select the table you want to search for records.
Enter the formula to filter records. For more details, refer to the
The formula will be evaluated for each record, and if the result is not
, includes the record in the response.
parameter, it returns only records in that view that satisfy the formula.
For example, to only include records where Name isn't empty, pass in
Specify sorting, if needed. The higher item in the list has precedence.
Select or map the view for the search results.
Add the fields you want to receive in the output. If no field is provided, all fields will be returned. It can be the field's name, for example,Â
, or the field's ID, for example,
Set the maximum number of records Make will return during one execution cycle. The default value is 10.
Select whether to use column ID instead of column name for mapping.

This enables persistence over the column name change. Enabling this option allows to replace entity keys in the response; instead of entity names specified as parameter keys, their identifiers will be specified. Changing this value will break all existing mappings in this
Retrieves a single record by its ID.

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: Select or map the base that contains the table you want to get a record from.
Select the table you want to get a record from.
Enter (map) the Record ID whose details you want to retrieve. Alternatively, you can use the search option to select the record.
Select whether to use column ID instead of column name for mapping.

This enables persistence over the column name change. Enabling this option allows to replace entity keys in the response; instead of entity names specified as parameter keys, their identifiers will be specified. Changing this value will break all existing mappings in this
Creates a new record in a Airtable.

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: Select or map the base that contains the table where you want to create a record.
Select the table where you want to create a record.
Enter values to the desired fields.
See Airtable's guide to basic field types
Enable this option if you want to enter names instead of record IDs to fields that link to another table. The record is automatically created in the linked table if there is no match.
Select whether to use column ID instead of column name for mapping.

This enables persistence over the column name change. Enabling this option allows to replace entity keys in the response; instead of entity names specified as parameter keys, their identifiers will be specified. Changing this value will break all existing mappings in this
Updates a record by its ID.

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: Select or map the base that contains the table whose records you want to update.
Select the table whose records you want to update.
Enter (map) the Record ID you want to update. You can retrieve the ID, for example, using the
module. Alternatively, you can use the
button to select the Record ID.
Enter values to the desired fields.
See Airtable's guide to basic field types
To delete the content of the field, use the
Enable this option if you want to enter names instead of record IDs to fields that link to another table. The record is automatically created in the linked table if there is no match.
Select whether to use column ID instead of column name for mapping.

This enables persistence over the column name change. Enabling this option allows to replace entity keys in the response; instead of entity names specified as parameter keys, their identifiers will be specified. Changing this value will break all existing mappings in this
Creates a new or updates an existing record.

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: Select or map the base that contains the table you want to update or create a record.
Select the table where you want to create or update a record.
Enter (map) the Record ID you want to update. You can retrieve the ID, for example, using the
module. Alternatively, you can use the
button to select the Record ID.
If you enter an ID that does not exist, an error occurs, and no action is performed.
Enter the values you want to update or create.
See Airtable's guide to basic field types
To delete the content of the field, use the
Select whether to use column ID instead of column name for mapping.

This enables persistence over the column name change. Enabling this option allows to replace entity keys in the response; instead of entity names specified as parameter keys, their identifiers will be specified. Changing this value will break all existing mappings in this
Deletes a record by its ID.

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: Select or map the base that contains the table you want to delete a record from.
Select the table you want to delete the record from.
Enter (map) the Record ID you want to delete. You can retrieve the ID, for example, using the
module. Alternatively, you can use the
button to select the Record ID.

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: Select or map the base that contains the table you want to create records in.
Select the table in which you want to create the records.
Enter values in the fields you want to create.
See Airtable's guide to basic field types

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: Select or map the base that contains the table whose records you want to update.
Select the table in which you want to update the records.
Enter values in the fields you want to update.
See Airtable's guide to basic field types

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: Select or map the base that contains the table where you want to upsert records
Select the table in which you want to upsert records.
Enter at least one and at most three field names or IDs to uniquely identify a single record.
Enter values in the fields you want to upsert.
See Airtable's guide to basic field types

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: Select or map the base that contains the table where you want to delete records.
Select the table for which you want to delete records.
Enter the IDs of the record you want to delete. You can retrieve the IDs, for example, using the
module. Alternatively, you can use the
button to select the Record IDs.
Allows you to perform a custom API call.

data.label: Airtable
data.overridedLabel: Create a connection to your Airtable account

children.text: For the list of available endpoints, refer to the
Select the HTTP method you want to use:
to retrieve information for an entry.
to make a partial entry update.
Enter the desired request headers. You don't have to add authorization headers; we already did that for you.
Enter the body content for your API call.

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
